summary: This document is an email chain from April 2020 between FBI public affairs specialists discussing a media inquiry from MailOnline UK. The inquiry asks the FBI to confirm if a Mutual Legal Assistance (MLA) request has been submitted to British authorities to question Prince Andrew as part of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The FBI personnel indicate a 'no comment' stance.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: A UK reporter inquires if the FBI has submitted a Mutual Legal Assistance request to British authorities to question Prince Andrew as part of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The media inquiry is regarding the FBI's investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Vivek Chaudhary
persons.context: The recipient of an automatic reply from the FBI National Press Office in December 2019 regarding a media inquiry.

connections.description: The FBI inquiry into Jeffrey Epstein includes a potential request to question Prince Andrew, indicating he is a person of interest in the investigation.

events.title: MailOnline UK inquiry to FBI
events.description: A reporter from MailOnline UK emails the FBI National Press Office to confirm if a Mutual Legal Assistance request has been submitted to question Prince Andrew regarding the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

events.title: Automatic reply from FBI National Press Office
events.description: The FBI National Press Office sends an automatic reply to an earlier media inquiry, indicating standard procedure for handling requests.

keyFacts: In April 2020, MailOnline UK inquired if the FBI had submitted a Mutual Legal Assistance request to British authorities to question Prince Andrew regarding the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.
FBI public affairs specialists internally discussed the inquiry, indicating a 'no comment' response was likely.
The inquiry suggests ongoing FBI investigative interest in Prince Andrew's connections to Jeffrey Epstein as of early 2020.
The email chain shows coordination between FBI New York and the FBI National Press Office in Washington, DC, regarding sensitive media inquiries.
